title: Quote of the Day: Tired of Chaos and Leaving House by the Dozens
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 3, 2024.
content: “All they know is how to use social media to burn the place down.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Where Do Those Painted White ‘Ghost Bikes’ Come From?
description: White bikes across the city serve as memorials — and calls for awareness about the dangers cyclists face.
content: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is Pants Sizing Sexist?
description: Our critic examines the history of women’s trousers and “the sheer ridiculousness of the current state of sizing.”
content: The question of men’s and women’s sizing is a much more complicated question than it may appear, in part because the whole concept of sizing is not standardized. It is, in fact, so fungible that it would send Hamlet around the bend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Julio Torres and Friends Toast Their Latest Bizarro Creation
description: The writer and director celebrated with a roomful of comedians on the rise before an advance screening of “Fantasmas,” his new HBO series.
content: “It’s not a bag,” said Julio Torres, indicating the purse that dangled from his shoulder on a delicate gold chain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Eliza Fawcett
title: 12-Year-Old Boy Is Charged in Killing of 15-Year-Old Cousin in Brooklyn
description: The 12-year-old was arrested hours after the police said he fatally shot another boy, Jasai Guy, in an apartment in the Brownsville neighborhood.
content: About 150 people gathered outside an apartment building in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn Monday evening for a somber purpose: to pay tribute to Jasai Guy, a 15-year-old boy who, the police said, had been fatally shot by a 12-year-old cousin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ioan Grillo
title: Mexico’s New President Has a Daunting Job: Stop the Blood Bath
description: Claudia Sheinbaum has shown she can take a pragmatic approach to crime.
content: In a village in the hills of Guerrero State, residents ran from their homes as drones flew overhead, dropping makeshift bombs. For months, drug cartel operatives had been deploying the commercial devices to drop explosives packed into metal casings, setting homes ablaze, tearing holes in walls and sending piercing hot shrapnel into people’s flesh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Time Flies When You’re Being Convicted
description: Is it still true that there’s no such thing as bad publicity?
content: Gail Collins: Bret, since we last conversed, Donald Trump was convicted on 34 felony charges. Time sure flies. Any thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: For Her Third Album, Angélica Garcia Adds Her First Language: Spanish
description: “Gemelo” is a largely electronic exploration of all kinds of dualities: “With any music I make from now on, I’m going to be writing in both languages.”
content: “My blood speaks Spanish to me,” Angélica Garcia sang in “Red Moon Rising,” a track on her 2016 debut album, “Medicine for Birds.” Garcia, who was born in California, was living in Virginia; the album leaned toward indie-rock and Americana. But the lyric turned out to be prophetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,080, June 3, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: ‘Lock Her Up’ Was Not Just a Slogan
description: Donald Trump’s second term would be even more corrupt and vindictive than his first.
content: A truism of the Trump era is that every accusation is a confession. When Donald Trump hurls wild charges at his opponents, he is telegraphing what he plans to do to them, pre-emptively justifying the breaking of laws and norms by casting himself as the victim of the very misdeeds he’s going to commit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Mexico Elects Claudia Sheinbaum
description: We explain why so many Mexican citizens are happy with their country’s direction.
content: When foreigners hear news from Mexico, it can often sound chaotic, involving cartels, crime or migration surges. But last night’s election results make clear that most Mexicans are pleased with their country’s direction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump as Felon: The Fallout
description: Readers counter his supporters’ criticism of the verdict and cite his history of fraudulent behavior. Also: A plea for shorter campaigns; inaction on guns; Elon Musk.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Trump Almost Certainly Won’t Go on Trial in Georgia This Year. Here’s Why.
description: The state appeals court tentatively set oral arguments for October on whether the prosecutor in the Georgia election interference case should be disqualified.
content: With a one-page order, the Georgia Court of Appeals on Monday made it all the more likely that Donald J. Trump will not face a criminal trial in the state before he faces off against President Biden in the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Marc Tracy
title: Holocaust Museums Debate What to Say About the Israel-Hamas War
description: Students are bringing up antisemitic tropes and asking survivors and docents: What is Palestine? Is there a genocide in Gaza?
content: At a Holocaust museum in Atlanta, staff members had typically ended their tours by saying that many survivors of the death camps immigrated to Palestine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Mexico Joins List of Latin American Nations That Have Elected Female Presidents
description: In contrast to the United States, the region has had more than a dozen female leaders, many in democracies that were once under the sway of authoritarian governments.
content: The presidential election in the United States this year is, yet again, a contest between two men. But in Latin America, as Mexico’s milestone election showed over the weekend, electing a woman as president has become remarkably routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: What Are Eco-Friendly Ways to Control Backyard Bugs?
description: Meet the “bucket of doom” and other methods to manage mosquitoes and ticks.
content: Just as the weather calls us to long evenings outdoors in short sleeves and sundresses, mosquitoes show up. At best, they’re annoying. At worst, they spread disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
description: Elections starting this week for the European Parliament could leave far-right parties with more power than ever, but also expose the fissures among them.
content: Nationalists are surging and expected to make big gains when voters from 27 nations cast ballots starting this week for the European Parliament. But the prospect of success is already raising the question among far-right parties of how far is too far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Two N.Y.P.D. Officers Are Shot Overnight in Queens
description: The officers were trying to pull over a man they said was riding a motorbike the wrong way down a one-way street. The officers and the man, who was also shot, are expected to survive.
content: Two police officers were shot early Monday morning in Queens in a shootout with a 19-year-old man whom they had tried to pull over for riding a motorbike the wrong way down a one-way street, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Kilauea Volcano Erupts on Hawaii’s Big Island
description: The volcano erupted three times in 2023. There did not appear to be any immediate danger to residents on Monday.
content: Kilauea, the most active volcano in Hawaii, began erupting early on Monday morning. Kilauea, in the southeast part of the Big Island, erupted three times last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: The Alternative to Huge Cruises? 3 Masts, 28 Sails and Wind Power.
description: We checked out the 136-passenger Sea Cloud Spirit on a Mediterranean cruise. In this era of gargantuan ships, its elegant clipper design, wooden decks and relatively small size stands out.
content: From the bridge of the three-masted windjammer, the Sea Cloud Spirit, the captain called out the words we’d all been waiting for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 359, June 4, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Voters in Mexico Cement the Governing Party’s Dominance
description: Expectations were high for the leftist Morena party, and it exceeded them, potentially giving President-elect Claudia Sheinbaum and her allies the power to enact systemic change.
content: The margin of Claudia Sheinbaum’s election as Mexico’s president was the biggest in decades, and even as the votes were still being counted on Monday, it became clear that Mexico’s leftist governing party and its allies could be in a position to reshape the country’s political landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Rep. Jamaal Bowman Loses Support of an Ex-Colleague Over Israel
description: Mondaire Jones, a fellow Black progressive who entered Congress with Mr. Bowman after the 2020 election, is endorsing Mr. Bowman’s challenger, George Latimer.
content: Roughly four years ago, Mondaire Jones and Jamaal Bowman made history together. Young, left-leaning Democrats, they won hard-fought primaries in neighboring districts to become the first Black men ever to represent New York’s Westchester County in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Why Are Wineries Around the World Seeking This Certification?
description: Certificates of social and environmental responsibility, like B Corp status, have become important markers for wineries that place values front and center.
content: Grape growers and wine producers have long sought certifications testifying to their sustainable farming methods or their commitment to protecting the environment. They have taken great satisfaction in displaying their organic or biodynamic credentials. No less would be expected in a field that prides itself on offering a natural, agricultural product.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Join ‘The Daily’ Podcast at the Tribeca Festival
description: The show’s hosts, Michael Barbaro and Sabrina Tavernise, share how the podcast gets made in a special event on June 9 in New York City.
content: As context, nuance and history are vital to understanding current events, “The Daily,” the New York Times’s flagship news podcast, follows one story a day, helping to create a distinctive lens through which to view the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: A Sticking Point in Paramount and Skydance Talks: Who Pays For a Lawsuit?
description: A special committee of Paramount’s board of directors supports a merger with Skydance, a studio that has increased its offer in recent days. But the deal isn’t done yet.
content: Paramount and Skydance have haggled for months over an ambitious merger that would usher in a new ruler of a sprawling media kingdom that includes CBS, MTV and the film studio behind “Top Gun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Breeder Ordered to Pay $35 Million for Mistreating Beagles
description: Inotiv, whose subsidiaries pleaded guilty to two criminal counts, agreed to pay the record-setting amount. More than 4,000 beagles were rescued in 2022 from its facility in Virginia, where many were ill and injured.
content: A medical research company that bred dogs agreed on Monday to pay $35 million as part of a plea agreement for the mistreatment of more than 4,000 beagles that had to be rescued from its breeding facility in 2022 in Virginia, federal prosecutors said. The fine was the largest amount in an animal welfare case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Jennifer Schuessler
title: Harvard’s Largest Faculty Division Will No Longer Require Diversity Statements
description: Instead, the Faculty of Arts and Sciences will require applicants to describe their “efforts to strengthen academic communities,” a senior university leader said in an email.
content: Harvard’s Faculty of Arts and Sciences, the university’s largest division, said on Monday that it would no longer require job applicants to submit diversity statements, the latest shift at the university after months of turmoil over its values and the role of equity initiatives in higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Gold Bars, Steakhouse Dinners and Fast Talkers: The Menendez Trial
description: The trial of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey could last another month in federal court in Lower Manhattan.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the bribery trial of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey as it enters its fourth week in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman, Reid J. Epstein, Rachel Quester, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Mooj Zadie, Diana Nguyen, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: How Trump’s Conviction Could Reshape the Election
description: The guilty verdict in his Manhattan criminal trial is set to become a key piece in the 2024 campaign.
content: Last week, Donald J. Trump became the first U.S. former president to be convicted of a crime when a jury found that he had falsified business records to conceal a sex scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Terry Robards, 84, Dies; Lifted Fine Wines in America as a Times Critic
description: In columns and notably “The New York Times Book of Wine,” he introduced Americans to European and premium domestic varieties in the 1970s and ’80s.
content: Terry Robards, a former wine critic for The New York Times whose writing in the 1970s and ’80s helped Americans move beyond jug Chablis and cheap Chianti to explore regions and styles as far away — and, at the time, as exotic — as Burgundy and Tuscany and as close as upstate New York, died on May 23 at his home in Upper Jay, N.Y., near Lake Placid. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Thieme, Alissa Zhu and Jessica Gallagher
title: Seniors in Baltimore Are Being Devastated by Drugs: 5 Takeaways
description: The city has become the U.S. overdose capital, and older Black men are dying at higher rates than anyone else.
content: Over the past six years, Baltimore has endured one of America’s deadliest drug epidemics. Fatal overdoses have fallen surprisingly hard on one group: Black men currently in their mid-50s to early 70s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Trump’s Harder Line on Immigration Appears to Resonate, Polls Show
description: As the 2024 presidential election ramps up, here is what polls say about public views on the growing number of migrants.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has described his plans to remove large numbers of unauthorized immigrants from the country if elected to a second term by citing the mass deportations under President Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1950s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Plans Asylum Restrictions for Migrants
description: Also, Mexico elected its first woman president. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: President Biden is expected to sign an executive order tomorrow allowing him to temporarily seal the U.S. border with Mexico to migrants when crossings surge. The move, which is all but certain to be challenged in court, would represent the single most restrictive border policy instituted by Biden, or any other modern Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: For Past ‘Jeopardy!’ Contestants, Pop Culture Goes Beyond Gen Z
description: What, exactly, is the distinction between the new pop-culture spinoff of “Jeopardy!” and the original?
content: Ken Jennings, the record-holder for the most consecutive wins on “Jeopardy!,” once summarized the long-running quiz show as “shorthand for ‘smart,’” and said that it seemed to be beamed to viewers from “an eggheaded, alternate-reality America where television never dumbed down.” If entertainment does adhere to the poles suggested by Mr. Jennings — “Jeopardy!” being one, and “dumbed-down” television the other — then the forthcoming, streaming-only spinoff series, “Pop Culture Jeopardy!,” exists somewhere in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Thieme, Alissa Zhu and Jessica Gallagher
title: In Baltimore’s Senior Homes, Overdoses Plague a Forgotten Generation
description: Many are dying from fentanyl and other drugs. The hardest-hit are Black men in their 50s to 70s, a group that Baltimore’s changing economy left behind.
content: Larnell Robinson sat at a desk in his cluttered office last September, between a bookshelf full of Bibles and a table stacked with the overdose antidote Narcan. He slid out a list of residents of the West Baltimore high-rise where he was tenant council president — one of dozens of subsidized complexes that house the city’s poor seniors. One by one, he began scratching through names, conducting a grim accounting of the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New Yorkers Who Need Help With Rent Can (Finally) Join a List for Help
description: A waiting list for federal housing vouchers that has been closed for nearly 15 years is reopening, providing a lifeline for families struggling to afford the city’s high rent.
content: For the first time in 15 years, thousands of people who cannot afford to live in New York City may be able to get financial help through a highly sought-after federal program.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editor's Note
description: This audio container was published in error.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith and Jordyn Holman
title: Feeling Consumers’ Pain, Retailers Bring Back Discounts
description: The pandemic shopping boom led many stores and brands to widen profit margins by charging more. Now value is the watchword as shoppers grow choosier.
content: U.S. consumers, fatigued by a three-year bout of inflation, want lower prices. And large retailers that have increased prices, partly to contend with their own rising costs, appear to be responding to customer concerns — to an extent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Trump and R.N.C. Announce $141 Million Haul in May
description: The total, which was fueled in part by his criminal conviction and cannot be confirmed until filings this month, is likely to help Donald Trump close the cash gap with President Biden.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump and the Republican National Committee collected a combined $141 million in May, campaign officials said on Monday, an enormous haul fueled in part by his criminal conviction last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: What to Know About Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s Newly Elected President
description: Here are five key insights into Mexico’s new president as people wonder whether she will diverge from Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s policies or focus on cementing his legacy.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has a Ph.D in energy engineering, participated in a United Nations panel of climate scientists awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and governed the capital, one of the largest cities in the hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘Clipped,’ Cleopatra Coleman Spreads Her Wings
description: The actor’s versatility has allowed her to stay relatively anonymous, but that may change with her new docudrama about an N.B.A. scandal.
content: Cleopatra Coleman began with red, swirling it toward pink with a fine-tipped brush. An oval appeared on the paper, and then smaller marks joined it — ears, eyebrows, a line for a nose. “I always draw this woman,” Coleman said. “I don’t know why.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: Liberals Find a TV Prescription for Election Jitters: Monday Nights
description: Once a week, Rachel Maddow and Jon Stewart are luring viewers back to basic cable.
content: Liberal TV viewers have a new mantra: T.G.I.M.!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Goodell
title: The Heat Wave Scenario That Keeps Climate Scientists Up at Night
description: The hotter it gets, the more difficult it is for our bodies to cope.
content: On a recent Thursday evening, a freakish windstorm called a derecho (Spanish for “straight ahead”) hit Houston, a city of more than two million people that also happens to be the epicenter of the fossil fuel industry in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Israel Says 4 More Hostages Are Dead, Killed Months Ago in Gaza
description: The disclosure by the military was likely to add pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to move forward with a cease-fire deal.
content: The Israeli military said on Monday that four more hostages who were abducted in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks had died months ago in Gaza, a disclosure that was likely to add pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to move forward with a cease-fire deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Sheila Jackson Lee, Veteran Democrat in Congress, Has Pancreatic Cancer
description: The Texas congresswoman, who has served in the House for nearly three decades, said she had begun treatment and would work with leaders to be present for votes in Washington.
content: Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, Democrat of Texas, said on Sunday that she has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer but plans to continue her work in Congress as she undergoes treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Western U.S. Braces for Excessively High Temperatures as Heat Dome Arrives
description: Record-breaking temperatures that have contributed to deaths and power failures in Mexico are forecast to move north this week.
content: Severe heat is expected to bake parts of the United States from Texas to California starting on Tuesday, with temperatures soaring to the triple digits, according to the National Weather Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Armstrong
title: 7 Days in the Cultural Life of a MoMA Photography Curator
description: Oluremi Onabanjo fills her week with early morning writing sessions, a live show at the Village Vanguard, time with other Black scholars and art all around New York City.
content: As a curator in the photography department of the Museum of Modern Art, and a Ph.D. candidate in art history at Columbia, Oluremi C. Onabanjo squeezes as many exhibitions and talks as she can into an already packed schedule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Pantry Pasta Perfect for the Season
description: Ali Slagle’s new lemon-garlic linguine is light, bright and ready for the bits and bobs of summer produce and herbs that need using up.
content: My flight landed just before dinnertime last night. My family and I could easily have ordered in, but after four straight days of restaurant food — on a scouting trip for The New York Times — I craved the Zen of making dinner, which always soothes my travel frazzle. I wanted something fast, pantry-friendly and seasonal, to reflect this lovely warm weather we’ve been blessed with in the Northeast. Lo and behold, I found Ali Slagle’s lemon-garlic linguine, which checks every box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A New Search for Ripples in Space From the Beginning of Time
description: As it studies cosmic microwaves, the Simons Observatory in Chile aims to help prove or disprove cosmic inflation, a notion that the universe expanded rapidly in the moment after the Big Bang.
content: The universe burst into existence 13.8 billion years ago. What happened in that earliest moment is of intense interest to anyone trying to understand why everything is the way it is today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Singleton
title: Why Caffeine Can Make You Anxious
description: And what to do about it.
content: Brian Byrne, a tour manager in Los Angeles, was sipping a cold brew a few years ago when he started feeling clammy. Soon, his symptoms worsened: shallow breathing, a hollow feeling in his chest and a rapid, thumping heartbeat. He went outside to get air. “At that point, I was having racing thoughts, feeling like I was having a heart attack,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: GameStop Stock Surges Again on Social Media Buzz
description: A post on a long-dormant Reddit account suggested the trader known as Roaring Kitty had amassed a large stake in the video game retailer.
content: GameStop’s shares soared on Monday after the long-dormant Reddit account associated with Keith Gill, the trader known as Roaring Kitty, who helped spur 2021’s meme-stock mania, appeared to show a big stake in the video game retailer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria M. Walker
title: The Make-or-Break Question for a New Roommate: Do You Drink?
description: A Brooklyn woman who has been sober for three years needed a roommate. But alcohol would not be allowed in the apartment. Some people thought that was a joke.
content: When Shelby Cohen posted advertisements on Facebook for a new roommate in her Brooklyn apartment, she noted the most important details. She listed the bedroom’s dimensions, mentioned that there was just one bathroom, and noted nearby subway stations. But there was an important caveat for any potential roommate — no alcohol was allowed in the apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Prosecutor Drops Murder Charges Against Minnesota Trooper Amid Pushback
description: The prosecution of Ryan Londregan, a white Minnesota state trooper who fatally shot a Black motorist last year, sparked rare bipartisan outrage.
content: The top prosecutor in Minneapolis has dropped murder charges against a state trooper who fatally shot a motorist last year after a traffic stop, her office said on Sunday, a stunning turnaround in a case that ignited a political firestorm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Margot Benacerraf, Award-Winning Venezuelan Documentarian, Dies at 97
description: She made only two films, but her “Araya,” a rumination on the daily rituals of salt-mine laborers, became an enduring work of Latin American cinema.
content: Margot Benacerraf, a critically acclaimed Venezuelan documentary filmmaker whose hypnotic “Araya,” a visual tone poem chronicling the daily lives of salt workers on an austere peninsula on her country’s coast, shared the critics’ prize at the 1959 Cannes Film Festival, died on Wednesday in Caracas. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: MicroStrategy and Its Founder to Pay $40 Million in Tax Fraud Lawsuit
description: Michael Saylor did not pay any income taxes to Washington despite living there from 2005 through 2020, the attorney general for the District of Columbia said.
content: The attorney general for the District of Columbia reached a $40 million settlement with Michael Saylor and the software company he founded, MicroStrategy, in what the attorney general’s office said was the largest income tax fraud recovery in Washington history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Saumya Khandelwal
title: In Delhi’s Parched Slums, Life Hangs on a Hose and a Prayer
description: A heat wave has left water in short supply across India’s capital region. The poorest are left to crowd around tankers to get whatever they can.
content: Before the water tanker rolled into one of New Delhi’s largest slums, Arvind Kumar was pacing between the gate of a public school and a tea seller’s stall hundreds of yards from his home, where he lives with nine members of his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Young, Restless and Fired Up in the Cool Gray City of Love
description: Francine Prose’s new memoir, “1974,” looks back at her brief but transformative relationship with a countercultural champion.
content: Francine Prose married young, in her final semester at Radcliffe. The match was imperfect, and she and her husband both suffered. The cultural winds blew against them. The great music emerging from the car stereo was zero help. “The music we loved had come to seem like a reproach, a reminder: Someone is in love, but it isn’t you, and you will never feel like that again,” Prose writes in her new memoir, “1974: A Personal History.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: U.C. Strike to Expand to Three More Campuses
description: Graduate teaching assistants and researchers plan to walk off the job at U.C. Santa Barbara, U.C. San Diego and U.C. Irvine, a week before final exams.
content: For most of the University of California system, the last week of classes for the spring quarter begins today. But it’s likely to be disrupted on a number of campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Eileen Sullivan
title: Family Turns Out to Support Hunter Biden as Jury Is Selected in Gun Trial
description: The president’s son is on trial in Wilmington, Del., on three charges that he lied about his drug use on a federal firearms application in 2018. The unusual prosecution carries stiff penalties: up to 25 years in prison and a $750,000 fine.
content: Follow our live updates of Hunter Biden’s trial in a gun case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Puerto Rico Governor Loses Primary to Former Ally
description: Representative Jenniffer González-Colón, the island’s nonvoting member of Congress, defeated Gov. Pedro R. Pierluisi four years after they appeared on the same ticket.
content: Gov. Pedro R. Pierluisi of Puerto Rico lost his bid for a second term on Sunday, suffering a rare defeat by a sitting governor on the island after a rancorous primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: A Senator’s Son Fights for Political Survival
description: This year’s political landscape is consumed with trials and powerful family entanglements.
content: All eyes have been on the hush-money trial of former President Donald Trump in Manhattan, and the question on everyone’s mind is how his guilty verdict might shape the November election. But there’s another trial taking place in Manhattan that has already turned politics upside down — at least, in New Jersey. I asked my colleague Tracey Tully, The New York Times’s indomitable New Jersey correspondent, to tell us more. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Menendez, on Trial, Files to Run for Re-election as an Independent
description: Several men dropped off the paperwork in Trenton, N.J., while the senator was in a federal courthouse in Manhattan. He has until the middle of August to withdraw.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, a lifelong Democrat who is in his fourth week of a federal bribery trial, filed paperwork Monday to run for re-election as an independent in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Davis and Kiuko Notoya
title: Toyota and Other Japanese Carmakers Say They Mishandled Safety Tests
description: The Japanese authorities had told the companies to conduct investigations into their compliance with national standards for safety and other issues.
content: Toyota Motor, Honda Motor and other top Japanese automakers said on Monday that internal investigations found they had mishandled vehicle testing on dozens of models over the past decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Jacob Zuma Gets His Revenge on South African Party That Shunned Him
description: A new party led by Mr. Zuma, a former president forced out over corruption allegations, helped ensure that the African National Congress fell short of an outright majority for the first time since the end of apartheid.
content: Jacob Zuma’s political career could have ended when he was forced to resign six years ago as South Africa’s president over corruption allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Guide to Managing Covid This Summer
description: Experts say cases could rise in the coming weeks. Here’s what to know about symptoms, testing and treatment.
content: As new variants of the coronavirus continue to gain traction, doctors and researchers are bracing for a potential rise in cases this summer. KP.2, one of these variants, now accounts for 28.5 percent of cases, and data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows a small increase in Covid-related emergency room visits and positive tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Stolen Remains Found in Plastic Bag Traced to Woman Born 160 Years Ago
description: Skeletal remains found in Oxnard, Calif., in 1985 have been identified as those of Gertrude Elliott-Littlehale, a musician whose grave was desecrated after her death in 1915.
content: In October 1985, partial skeletal remains were found in a plastic bag in the Channel Islands Harbor in Oxnard, Calif., northwest of Los Angeles. The authorities determined that they belonged to a woman who died when she was between 35 and 50 years old, but nothing else about her was known and, for decades, the trail went cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Ernesto Londoño
title: A Mazda, a Gift Bag of $120,000 and a Dismissed Juror
description: A stranger dropped off cash at a juror’s house and offered more if she voted to acquit defendants charged with defrauding federal food programs.
content: On the eve of the closing day of a federal fraud trial in Minneapolis, a woman drove up in a Mazda to a juror’s home holding a Hallmark gift bag emblazoned with butterflies and flowers. Inside were wads of $100, $50 and $20 bills totaling roughly $120,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dena Ibrahim
title: First They Came for Sudan’s Future. Now They’re Destroying Its Past.
description: There was no place for rogue militias in the Sudan we dreamed of.
content: On the evening of April 14, 2023, I was at a concert in Khartoum. The end of Ramadan was near, and the audience listened to the ouds, tambours and kanoons of Bait Al Oud, an orchestra set up to preserve traditional Sudanese instruments. I sang along to songs made popular by the 2019 revolution and then floated home, my spirits high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: During Impassioned Defense of Trump, Congressman’s 6-Year-Old Steals the Spotlight
description: As Representative John Rose castigated the former president’s criminal conviction, his young son locked in with the C-SPAN cameras, making a series of contorted faces in a moment that circulated widely online.
content: Fresh back from a weeklong recess, Representative John W. Rose, Republican of Tennessee, was fired up and among the first to speak on the House floor on Monday, when he used his five minutes of floor time to castigate the criminal conviction of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A Climate Scientist Is Voted President of an Oil Country. Now What?
description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s next leader, is an academic and a politician. Here’s what her track record reveals.
content: Mexico is the world’s 11th-largest oil producer. It has been gripped by a deadly heat wave. Now, it’s elected as its president a woman with a rare pedigree: a left-of-center climate scientist with a doctorate in energy engineering named Claudia Sheinbaum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Is No. 1 Again, With Little Competition on the Way
description: “The Tortured Poets Department” earns a sixth week atop the Billboard 200, while the latest from Twenty One Pilots opens at No. 3 with big numbers for a rock album.
content: How much longer can Taylor Swift hold at No. 1 with “The Tortured Poets Department”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.9 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury retreat in Palm Springs, a 2021 townhouse in West Hollywood and a 1912 Craftsman bungalow in San Diego.
content: This 1957 house, recently used as a vacation rental, was designed by Palmer & Krisel, an architecture firm responsible for numerous midcentury tract homes in the area. It is a few blocks from popular resorts on East Palm Canyon Drive, one of the city’s main thoroughfares, and less than a 10-minute drive from downtown. Joshua Tree National Park is about an hour away. Driving to Los Angeles takes two hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Brexit Champion Says He’ll Run for Parliament, Jolting U.K. Election
description: Nigel Farage, an anti-immigration campaigner and Trump ally, reversed a pledge not to run. His Reform U.K. party hopes to take seats from Conservatives.
content: Nigel Farage, the pro-Brexit campaigner and serial disrupter of British politics, announced plans on Monday to run as a candidate in Britain’s general election next month, dealing a new setback to the prospects of the country’s embattled prime minister, Rishi Sunak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Larry Bensky, a Fixture of Left-Wing Radio, Is Dead at 87
description: A self-described activist-journalist, he was for many years the national affairs correspondent for the community-focused Pacifica network.
content: Larry Bensky, a radio journalist whose reporting on major political events made him the signature voice of Pacifica Radio, a network of progressive, listener-supported stations, died on May 19 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Fauci Grilled by Lawmakers on Masks, Vaccine Mandates and Lab Leak Theory
description: Dr. Fauci testified before a House panel investigating Covid’s origins. The panel found emails suggesting that his aides were skirting public records laws.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the former government scientist both celebrated and despised for his work on Covid, on Monday forcefully denied Republican allegations that he had helped fund research that sparked the pandemic or had covered up the possibility it originated in a laboratory, calling the accusations “absolutely false and simply preposterous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Emad Mekay and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Seizure of Gaza Border Zone Strains Ties With Egypt
description: Israel defied ominous Egyptian warnings and took control of the Philadelphi Corridor, but the reaction from Egypt, which wants to maintain its security cooperation with Israel, has been muted.
content: For weeks, talk show hosts and newspaper columnists across Egypt’s government-managed media spoke with one voice: Any Israeli “occupation” of a buffer zone on the Egypt-Gaza border could violate Egypt’s sovereignty and national security. That would deal a further blow to a relationship that Israel’s offensive had already pushed to its lowest point in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Netanyahu’s Far-Right Partners Reject Cease-Fire Compromise
description: Two coalition members threatened to topple Israel’s government if Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accepted a deal for a cease-fire and the release of hostages that stopped short of Hamas’s total destruction.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel maneuvered into rougher political waters on Monday, as two far-right partners threatened to bring down his government should Israel agree to a cease-fire deal that would end the war in Gaza without eliminating Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Are Wedding Sneakers the Ultimate Power Flex?
description: Rupert Murdoch’s fifth marriage, this time to Elena Zhukova, seemed a casual affair, though some disapproved of the suit-sneaker combination.
content: As a rule of thumb, sneakers with suits are a terrible idea. Unless, perhaps, you are Rupert Murdoch, the 93-year-old billionaire media mogul who — seeming to chase Elizabeth Taylor’s lifetime tally of eight marriages — married his fifth wife on Saturday in a ceremony at his Tuscan-style vineyard in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Electric Cars Are Suddenly Becoming Affordable
description: More efficient manufacturing, falling battery costs and intense competition are lowering sticker prices for battery-powered models to within striking distance of gasoline cars.
content: Alex Lawrence, a dealer in Salt Lake City who specializes in used electric cars, has seen a change over the last year in the kinds of customers who are coming into his showroom. They used to be well-heeled professionals who could drop $70,000 on a Rivian luxury pickup truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
title: New York Has a Week to Pass Bills on Social Media and Plastics. Will It?
description: Lawmakers in Albany are rushing to address various environmental and health-related initiatives, with just a week left in the 2024 legislative session.
content: In New York, the state legislative session runs for roughly 60 days spread out from January to early June, but most of the actual passing of bills occurs over two periods. The first is when the state passes its budget, a document so overstuffed with unrelated bills that it’s known around the State Capitol as the “big ugly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Consumer Bureau to Create ‘Corporate Offender’ Registry
description: Most companies will be required to report government and court orders penalizing them for consumer protection violations.
content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Monday finalized a plan to create a public registry of nonbank businesses that have been penalized for violating consumer protection laws, a roster some have called a “rap sheet” for companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa and Vanessa Friedman
title: When Anti-Fur Protesters Are at the Front Door
description: The designer Marc Jacobs said he was bullied into renouncing fur — which he claims his brand stopped using in 2018 — after activists targeted his employees.
content: A new frontier has opened in fashion’s fur wars, as protesters targeted the homes of more than a dozen employees of Marc Jacobs in recent months, using signs, noisemakers and fake blood in an effort to force the designer to officially renounce the use of fur in his collections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Arrest Threatens Nepal’s Standing as South Asia’s Model for Free Speech
description: A media executive was arrested after his company published critical reports about a powerful government minister.
content: In a region sliding toward authoritarianism one country after another, the small Himalayan nation of Nepal was a shining exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Bell
title: In This Experimental Grief Novel, You Choose Your Own Adventure
description: Gabriel Smith’s shape-shifting debut, “Brat,” cycles through a multiverse of strange possibilities.
content: In the wake of his father’s death and his mother’s move to a nursing facility, a 20-something British novelist named Gabriel (not to be confused with the 20-something British novelist Gabriel Smith, whose debut, “Brat,” he inhabits) returns home.  Ostensibly, he’s there to prepare his parents’ estate for sale, but he’s also hiding out from a multitude of problems. For starters, despite receiving a sizable advance for his second book, Gabriel hasn’t written a word yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Manuela Andreoni
title: Deadly Floods in Brazil Were Worsened by Climate Change, Study Finds
description: The country’s south received three months’ rain in two weeks. Global warming has made such deluges twice as likely as before, scientists said.
content: Human-caused warming has doubled the chances that southern Brazil will experience extreme, multiday downpours like the ones that recently caused disastrous flooding there, a team of scientists said on Monday. The deluges have killed at least 172 people and displaced more than half a million residents from their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Car Deals Vanished During the Pandemic. They’re Coming Back.
description: Automakers and dealers are starting to offer discounts, low-interest loans and other incentives to lure buyers as the supply of cars grows.
content: For much of the last four years, automakers and their dealers had so few cars to sell — and demand was so strong — that they could command high prices. Those days are over, and hefty discounts are starting a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Is Expected to Sign Order Letting Him Seal Border With Mexico
description: The move, expected on Tuesday, would allow the president to temporarily close the border and suspend longtime protections for asylum seekers in the United States.
content: President Biden is expected to sign an executive order on Tuesday allowing him to temporarily seal the U.S. border with Mexico to migrants when crossings surge, a move that would suspend longtime protections for asylum seekers in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
title: Abnormally Dry Canada Taps U.S. Energy, Reversing Usual Flow
description: Lower-than-normal rain and snow have reduced Canada’s hydropower production, raising worries in the industry about the effects of climate change.
content: In February, the United States did something that it had not done in many years — the country sent more electricity to Canada than it received from its northern neighbor. Then, in March, U.S. electricity exports to Canada climbed even more, reaching their highest level since at least 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: People With Criminal Records React to Trump Verdict: ‘Now You Understand’
description: The New York jury’s decision stirred conflicting emotions, including surprise at the responses of many on the left.
content: Some Democratic leaders are eager to make former President Donald J. Trump’s new identity as a convicted criminal central to their pitch to voters on why he is unfit for office. At the same time, there has been a movement on the left for years to end the stigma of criminal records and point out grave issues in the country’s legal system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Lengel
title: Ford Rescues a Detroit Train Station as It Plots Its Own Future
description: The automaker paid $90 million for the ravaged Michigan Central Station in 2018, and will spend millions more to create a hub of businesses focused on transportation.
content: When he was growing up in Southwest Detroit, Cristian Rubio was never all that curious about the shuttered train station that loomed over his neighborhood. The building, a couple of miles west of downtown, was among the city’s most visible symbols of urban decay and a go-to for photographers who wanted to capture its decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Research Finds Significant Racial Disparities in Medicaid Re-enrollment
description: Among those who could not complete the process of renewing their Medicaid coverage, Black and Hispanic Americans were twice as likely as white people to lose their health insurance, a new study found.
content: Black and Hispanic Americans were twice as likely as white Americans to lose Medicaid last year because of an inability to complete renewal forms during a vast trimming of the program’s rolls, according to a study published on Monday in the journal JAMA Internal Medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller, Brendan Embser, Emmanuel Iduma and Lucy McKeon
title: The 25 Photos That Defined the Modern Age
description: A group of experts met to discuss the images that have best captured — and changed — the world since 1955.
content: Let’s get this out of the way first: Of the dozens of photographers not represented here that a reasonable person might expect to have been included, the most conspicuous absentees include Berenice Abbott, Ansel Adams, Robert Adams, Richard Avedon, Dawoud Bey, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Imogen Cunningham, Roy DeCarava, William Eggleston, Walker Evans, Robert Mapplethorpe, Helmut Newton and Irving Penn. Putting together a list of the 25 most significant photographs since 1955 — both fine art photos and reportage — proved a difficult task for the panelists (even the chosen time frame was controversial). They were: the Canadian conceptual photographer Stan Douglas, 63; the Vietnamese American photographer An-My Lê, 64; the acting chief curator of Photography at the Museum of Modern Art, Roxana Marcoci, 66; the American documentary photographer Susan Meiselas, 75; the American photographer Shikeith, 35; and Nadia Vellam, 51, T’s photo and video director. Each participant (including myself, the moderator, 36) submitted up to seven possible nominees for the list. We gathered at The New York Times Building on a morning last February (with Shikeith joining on video from a shoot in Los Angeles) to begin our deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: South Africa rejects the party that ended apartheid.
content: The African National Congress lost its political monopoly in South Africa for the first time since vanquishing the country’s last white-led regime 30 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: Beijing Claims U.K. Recruited Chinese State Officials as Spies
description: The accusation from China came a few weeks after Britain charged three men with assisting Hong Kong’s intelligence service.
content: China’s top security ministry accused Britain’s MI6 intelligence agency on Monday of persuading a married couple working for unnamed central Chinese government bodies to become spies for the British government, the latest in a volley of continuing espionage accusations between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Smith Henderson
title: Can a Novel Tell Us How Ted Kaczynski Became the Unabomber?
description: Maxim Loskutoff’s “Old King” is set in the remote forests of Montana, where one resident began a campaign to destroy modern life as we know it.
content: Ted Kaczynski may already have been harboring considerable resentments by his second year at Harvard, where the awkward, 17-year-old math prodigy lived in a dorm for similarly gifted students. He was under a lot of pressure from his parents to succeed. He’d skipped grades and missed out on building relationships with peers. He was socially isolated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,081, June 4, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Reread a Book That Changed My Life, but I’d Changed, Too
description: At the very least, it’s a chance to remember who we were when we first experienced it.
content: On the day of the eclipse back in April, walking through Boston Common on a fine spring afternoon as every expectant face turned upward, I thought again of Annie Dillard’s wondrously dislocating essay “Total Eclipse,” which I have reread more times than I can count. “My hands were silver,” she wrote. “All the distant hills’ grasses were finespun metal that the wind laid down.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Jäger
title: My Country Shows What Europe Has Become
description: For all its singularity, Belgium tells a quintessentially European story.
content: He could have been anywhere. Delivering a speech to a group of Belgian businessmen this year, Barack Obama warned about the dangers of artificial intelligence, climate change and geopolitical conflict. More local matters were close at hand: Belgium was entering an election year, and its capital, Brussels, home to some of Europe’s most hallowed institutions, had weathered a year of geopolitical shocks. Yet Mr. Obama wouldn’t be drawn into questions about national politics. A visit to the Magritte Museum and the king was the extent of his engagement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Adventures in Space and Time With Stockhausen
description: It is nearly impossible to stage Stockhausen’s seven-opera cycle “Licht.” But “Inside Light” brings a portion of it to the Park Avenue Armory.
content: An elliptical halo of thin, concentrated light floated in the capacious drill hall of the Park Avenue Armory on a recent morning, above a circular area designed to dissolve your sense of space and time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
title: Sally Buzbee, Washington Post Editor, to Leave Role
description: Matt Murray, the former editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, will take her place temporarily.
content: The executive editor of The Washington Post, Sally Buzbee, will leave her role, a major and sudden change at one of the nation’s pre-eminent news organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In Former Soviet States, a Tug of War Between East and West
description: Geopolitical rivalry, intensified by fighting in Ukraine, is amplifying domestic struggles in countries like Georgia and Moldova whose people are split on which side to support.
content: In Georgia, protesters waving European Union flags have rallied against what they see as their pro-Russia leaders. Moldova’s government is pushing to join the western bloc, enraging citizens hoping for closer relations with Moscow. Armenia, too, has reached out to Europe, angered that Moscow, a longtime ally, is courting its enemy, Azerbaijan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: introspection
description: This word has appeared in 75 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word introspection has appeared in 75 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 1 in “What’s ‘In’ for 2024? In-and-Out Lists, Apparently” by Jessica Roy:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Crypto Bull’s Big Tax Settlement
description: The technology company MicroStrategy and its founder, Michael Saylor, agreed to a $40 million deal to end a lawsuit accusing him of evading income tax.
content: The attorney general for the District of Columbia has reached a $40 million settlement with the billionaire Bitcoin investor Michael Saylor and MicroStrategy, the software company he founded, over tax fraud, DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch is first to report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Should Biden Downplay His Own Success?
description: A radical idea: The administration should just tell the truth.
content: The performance of America’s economy over the past two years has been remarkable, especially given the dire predictions of many observers. Remember the economists who forecast a recession in 2023? Remember all those warnings that getting inflation down would require years of high unemployment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Verena Hölzl
title: A Myanmar Rebel Group Is Accused of Persecuting Rohingya
description: Allegations against the Arakan Army, a key force in the fight against the junta, threaten to revive old horrors of sectarian atrocities.
content: International courts are still investigating the Myanmar military’s slaughter of the country’s Rohingya Muslim minority in 2017 that the United States has called a genocide. Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh and those who stayed faced persecution from the junta. Now a new threat to the group is looming, this time at the hands of a powerful rebel force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: Washington Post Newsroom Reels From Its Editor’s Sudden Exit
description: Sally Buzbee, who has been editor of The Washington Post since 2021, chafed at a major reorganization by the newspaper’s chief executive.
content: On Sunday night, minutes after Will Lewis, the chief executive of The Washington Post, informed employees that the newspaper’s executive editor, Sally Buzbee, was being replaced, managers gathered on a conference call to hear from their boss one last time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Another Milestone in Mexico: Its First Jewish President
description: Claudia Sheinbaum was born to Jewish parents, but she has played down her heritage on the campaign trail.
content: Mexico elected its first Jewish president over the weekend, a remarkable step in a country with one of the world’s largest Catholic populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Steven Lee Myers
title: Fake News Reports and Videos Seek to Undermine the Paris Olympics
description: Russian propagandists are spoofing broadcasters and mimicking French and U.S. intelligence agencies to stoke fear about security at the Games.
content: With its athletes barred from competing in the Summer Olympics under the country’s flag, Russia has turned its fury on the Games and this year’s host, Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: The Man Who Couldn’t Stop Going to College
description: Benjamin B. Bolger has spent his whole life amassing academic degrees. What can we learn from him?
content: Benjamin B. Bolger has been to Harvard and Stanford and Yale. He has been to Columbia and Dartmouth and Oxford, and Cambridge, Brandeis and Brown. Over all, Bolger has 14 advanced degrees, plus an associate’s and a bachelor’s. Some of Bolger’s degrees took many years to complete, such as a doctorate from the Harvard Graduate School of Design. Others have required rather less commitment: low-residency M.F.A.s from Ashland University and the University of Tampa, for example.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: 8 Comics to Read This Pride Month
description: These comics and graphic novels have superheroes and supervillains, and drama at theater camp. There is also a nonfiction guide to coming out.
content: This collection of comics and graphic novels, a mix of nonfiction and fiction stories, have settings as disparate as a cabin in the woods and a 24-hour convenience store. What unites them is that they all star L.G.B.T.Q. protagonists. Happy Pride!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Mexico Elects Its First Woman President
description: Also, the U.S. is poised to change its asylum policy.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum, a climate scientist and former mayor of Mexico City, will be Mexico’s next president, after winning a landslide victory in elections. She will be the first woman, and the first Jewish person, to hold the post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Natalie Kitroeff, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Mexico Elects First Female President, and Hunter Biden Goes on Trial
description: Plus, Simone Biles sets a record.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: Lots of Bravo and ‘Fantasmas’
description: “Summer House” and “The Valley” wrap up as “Below Deck Mediterranean” starts a new season. HBO airs a new show from Julio Torres.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, June 3-9. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Floods Break Dams and Submerge Highways in Southern Germany
description: Several towns declared states of emergency and evacuated citizens as water submerged streets and highways and derailed a high-speed train.
content: After a weekend of heavy rains, severe floods in regions of southern Germany led several towns to declare states of emergency and to evacuate their citizens from heavily affected areas. Water submerged streets and highways, broke dams and derailed a high-speed train. Even as rain let up on Monday, emergency crews rushed to fortify dams along rivers in anticipation of further flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Janis Paige, Star of Broadway’s ‘The Pajama Game,’ Is Dead at 101
description: She first made her mark in the all-star 1944 movie “Hollywood Canteen” before finding acclaim on the musical stage. Movie and TV roles followed.
content: Janis Paige, an entrancing singer, dancer and actress who starred in the original 1954 Broadway production of the hit musical “The Pajama Game,” died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Many Literary A.I. Characters and Plots Do You Know?
description: Some science fiction authors have been using the concept of artificial intelligence in their books for decades. Try this short quiz to see how many works you remember.
content: Some science fiction authors have been using the concept of artificial intelligence in their books for decades. Try this short quiz to see how many works you remember.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marco Hernandez, Jeffrey Gettleman, Finbarr O'Reilly and Tim Wallace
title: What Ukraine Has Lost
description: We measured every town, street and building blown apart in Ukraine to show the first comprehensive picture of where people can’t return home.
content: We measured every town, street and building blown apart in Ukraine to show the first comprehensive picture of where people can’t return home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 30, 2024
description: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
content: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alina Chan
title: Why the Pandemic Probably Started in a Lab, in 5 Key Points
description: The world must not continue to bear the intolerable risks of research with the potential to cause pandemics.
content: The world must not continue to bear the intolerable risks of research with the potential to cause pandemics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li
title: Kilauea Volcano Erupts in Hawaii
description: Kilauea, the most active volcano in Hawaii, began erupting early on Monday morning.
content: Kilauea, the most active volcano in Hawaii, began erupting early on Monday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Zhu, Rebecca Suner and Claire Hogan
title: Behind the Reporting
description: Baltimore is experiencing one of the worst fatal overdose crises in American history. Alissa Zhu, a New York Times local reporting fellow with The Baltimore Banner, explains the impacts of the crisis.
content: Baltimore is experiencing one of the worst fatal overdose crises in American history. Alissa Zhu, a New York Times local reporting fellow with The Baltimore Banner, explains the impacts of the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times
